meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines
meeting_annotations.transcript: and we discovered a lot of those linkages were very important. meeting_annotations.speaker: Venkat Viswanathan
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay maybe I'll just walk through what what all I I digested and and maybe you can also capture what I didn't digest. So so I think the initial discussions we discussed a few of the industries where there are locked in CO2 emissions so they may need to be paired with negative emission. And then we started out by wanting to identify whether there are sectors that would use the same process capture CO2 and pair or invent new processes without emissions. So identifying that boundary which may go to the next slide and then we all talked about ways to accelerate the timeline for progress for these areas. Community engagement, lots of discussion there. And then natural solutions tend to have a greater preference for adoption versus technological solutions. And then there were points around I was thinking about it from an investment thesis perspective, quantifying strengths and quantifying these metrics are crucial. Then second here we discussed about sectors that are easier quote unquote easy to decarbonize versus not. So here we put electricity production. I guess I added transportation as my own opinion maybe maybe people don't agree. And then some that I guess many agreed as hard is steel, cement, large vehicles and food. And so should should who uses negative emission depend on which of these two categories you fall in. And then and sort of you know this current decarbonization there's sort of two I guess enabling platforms. Solar and wind based electricity which can be then combined to do X where X is whatever transportation or other things. And then other angle is producing carbon neutral fuels. And then the sort of you know some of the other discussion around using other forms of existing infrastructure to be decarbonized. Co-benefits implementation and then we talked about the sort of integrated system view which led us into this tools category which I think was in my neat outline but you know if you had these tools you could analyze these problems much faster. There's a there's basically some consensus that this lack of good open source tools, there are some databases could be improved and verification is a challenge.

meeting_annotations.transcript: My comment that and thank you for that summary that it that that sort of puts into context a possible way to portray the situation which may not be accurate but one could think that in some respects negative emission technologies and science are a little bit disengaged with the economy and the industries that it is supposed to either mitigate or assist. How do we how do we move them from in the benchtop to to the economy?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's a great comment Peter. At at my lab working with RAND corporation we've just launched a new effort that we call Barriers to a Billion. What are the things that keep us from getting to a billion tons of negative emissions and it's a it's a real challenge. A lot of things on that list. Other thoughts? One of the things that that struck me in the Venkat's assessment was this issue of identifying what the emissions that are most appropriately dealt with by negative emissions might be and that many of those are going to be in the in the small categories and the things that aren't normally thought of and that that's certainly an important research topic of establishing the criteria for why you would call things appropriate for negative emissions and then what are those things? We're all so used to thinking about electric power and I kind of agree that electric power looks like it's handled or at least the technology is there.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Roger Aines
meeting_annotations.transcript: Julia what what science would you need to be more convincing to the UK government that they should be going this way?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Julia Brown
meeting_annotations.transcript: I mean I think there is I think there is a lot of work to to do with with our you know with industries like steel making. I mean we are I know we we have a number of programs in the UK looking at zero carbon steel making, looking at hydrogen reduction of steel and I know Tata Steel are actually supporting quite a lot of that thinking about what they might do. And I and I think there are some interesting opportunities as well because you get these silicate slags which you can which you can turn into carbonates and essentially use as a you know as a a negative you know as a negative emission element to the process. So I think there are some interesting studies to be done in some of these hard to decarbonize industries actually looking at all the steps of their processes and seeing what you could take out or what you could you could turn into a zero emissions or whether there might be a negative emission opportunity. But that requires quite a lot of detailed understanding of the individual chemical processes or manufacturing processes themselves. But I like your point about I like your point about the the small scale emissions because in general where we get emissions on a large scale we have some chance of capturing them or you know maybe it may be that the investment in finding a complete way of doing it is is very worthwhile. Where you get lots of very small emitters it can be that that can be very much much harder to do. I mean it's much harder to do with emissions from the tailpipe of a of a car than it is from a from a power station of course.

meeting_annotations.transcript: And that's in addition to a small emissions there's also the fugitive emissions right. So fugitive emissions are those cows that are grazing in the farms. And the landfills and other things.
